subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Review charts for Shavian Quikscript Extensions
msgSnippet: ... I think that s a requirement, yes.  We don t want a reader to read theft as feft and vice versa (though some people can t tell the difference). I prefer
messageBody:
Michael Everson scripsit:

> >Would it be possible in that case to have both scripts on the same page?
>
> ... then it does seem that Shaw might be supplemented by a Shqw which
> the text reader would have to be able to parse. Ranges tagged en_Shaw
> and ranges tagged en_Shqw would invoke different speech modules.

I think that's a requirement, yes. We don't want a reader to read
theft as feft and vice versa (though some people can't tell the
difference).

I prefer Shaq to Shqw on established principles of tagging script variation.

--
John Cowan http://www.ccil.org/~cowan cowan@...
"After all, would you consider a man without honor wealthy, even if his
Dinar laid end to end would reach from here to the Temple of Toplat?"
"No, I wouldn't", the beggar replied. "Why is that?" the Master asked.
"A Dinar doesn't go very far these days, Master. --Kehlog Albran
Besides, the Temple of Toplat is across the street." The Profit

Michael Everson scripsit:

> >Would it be possible in that case to have both scripts on the same page?
> 
> ... then it does seem that Shaw might be supplemented by a Shqw which 
> the text reader would have to be able to parse. Ranges tagged en_Shaw 
> and ranges tagged en_Shqw would invoke different speech modules.

I think that's a requirement, yes.  We don't want a reader to read
theft as feft and vice versa (though some people can't tell the
difference).

I prefer Shaq to Shqw on established principles of tagging script variation.

--
